questions.question: You are required not to exceed 50 km/h outside towns, in the following situations:

options.text: When the roadway is covered with slime
While driving on a slope
When meeting the indicator ‘Priority for circulation in opposite direction’.

questions.question: What are your obligations on meeting this indicator?

options.text: Not to exceed a speed of 50 km/h, as there is a potentially dangerous curve to the right
To reduce speed to 40 km/h and switch on the low beam
Not to overtake vehicles that transport goods.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed limit in cities?

options.text: 60 km/h
50 km/h
40 km/h.

questions.question: At what speed can you drive near a crossroad?

options.text: The maximum speed limit will be respected only in directed intersections
At a speed that allows stopping to grant priority to traffic participants who have this right
The maximum speed limit in cities is 50 km/h and outside towns 130 km/h.

questions.question: What are the maximum speeds permitted for vehicles in the subcategory B1?

options.text: 90 km/h on highways, 80 km/h on expressways or European national roads and 70 km/h on other types of roads
110 km/h on highways, 90 km/h on expressways and European national, 80 km/h on other types of roads
130 km/h on highways and 90 km/h on other types of roads.

questions.question: In which of these situations you are required to drive at reduced speeds?

options.text: When you are tired and the car has defective brakes
At railway level crossings
On county and municipal roads.

questions.question: Where does high speed often lead to accidents?

options.text: In intersections.
In parking lots
In driving polygons.

questions.question: Is the driver required to use the additional lane when climbing a slope if the speed is lower than that of the road sign?

options.text: No, because the lane is for vehicles traveling at speeds equal to or greater than that specified by the indicator
Yes
No, because he has to always drive on the lane close to the margin.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed limit outside localities, on national expressways or European roads (E)?

options.text: 100 km/h
110 km/h
90 km/h.

questions.question: At what speed will you make a left turn at an undirected intersection?

options.text: At a speed higher than the legal speed limit
At a maximum speed of 80 km/h
At a speed not exceeding 30 km/h in towns and 50 km/h outside towns.

questions.question: What should you do when entering a poorly lit street from one that is well illuminated?

options.text: The speed must be adapted to the new lighting conditions
You do not have any legal obligations
Drive as usual, as the vision adapts instantly.

questions.question: The speed must not exceed 30 km/h in towns and 50 km/h outside towns:

options.text: When visibility is less than 100 m in conditions of fog, heavy rain and snow
When driving on and under bridges
At the indicator ‘Priority for opposite traffic’.

questions.question: What do you do, when driving at the maximum speed allowed by law, you notice another car trying to overtake?

options.text: Do not increase speed and drive on the right side of the road, allowing the car to overtake
Signal using the lights that you understand the intention of the other vehicle to overtake
Use the horn and light signals, to alert the other driver that he exceeds the speed limit.

questions.question: The maximum speed allowed outside cities, when visibility is reduced below 100 m due to fog, is:

options.text: 70 km / h
50 km / h
90 km / h.

questions.question: If, for objective reasons, you drive slowly, you must:

options.text: Drive only on the lane close to the margin
Drive only on the lane near the axis, signaling with the hazard warning lights
Use the horn and light signals to prevent any possible event.

questions.question: In which of the following situations are you forced to not exceed 30 km/h in towns?

options.text: Within the range of the warning indicator "Accident"
When visibility is less than 100 m, due to fog
At intersections, when there are vehicles coming from the opposite direction.

questions.question: How do you drive carefully on icy roads, to avoid accidents?

options.text: Brake powerfully
Drive at reduced speeds and brake carefully to gauge how your vehicle reacts
Drive on the central axis of the road.

questions.question: Are you permitted to drive at speeds greater than the legal limit, in case of overtaking?

options.text: Yes, if you drive on the highway
Yes, if you make sure there is no oncoming vehicle
No.

questions.question: With what speed should you drive on public roads outside towns, when the road is covered with wet cubic stone?

options.text: At a speed not exceeding 50 km/h
At a speed which allows you to maneuver safely
At a speed not exceeding the maximum limit of 90 km/h.

questions.question: Speed must be reduced at the signal:

options.text: Of authorized workers on the public roads
Of railway officers
Of border guards.

questions.question: The indicator means:

options.text: A maximum allowed speed
A recommended speed
A mandatory minimum.

questions.question: The speed for a car on a highway, if the driver has less than a year of driving experience is:

options.text: 130 km/h
100 km/h

questions.question: The speed for a car on national roads, other than European roads(E), whose driver has less than a year of driving experience is;

options.text: 70 km/h
90 km/h
80 km/h.

questions.question: What obligations do you have regarding speed while driving?

options.text: To comply with the maximum speed which corresponds to the category of vehicle you drive
To comply with speed limits imposed by specific signaling
To drive as far as possible in lower gears, not to pollute the environment.

questions.question: When it is not allowed to increase the speed of a car?

options.text: When driving on the first lane
When another vehicle is overtaking you
In intersections.

questions.question: A driver with less than a year of driving experience will drive at speeds lesser than maximum speed outside the city, by:

options.text: 10 km / h
20 km / h
25 km / h.

questions.question: What obligations do you have when you are overtaken by another vehicle?

options.text: To reduce the speed
Not to increase speed
To drive as close as possible to the margin of the road or lane you are driving.

questions.question: Speed should be reduced to 30 km/h in towns and 50 km/h outside towns:

options.text: When you pass by organized groups, military columns or processions, when the road has only one lane in each direction
At the indicator “Mandatory bicycle track”
At railway level crossings with double or simple barriers.

questions.question: When driving a car towing a trailer on a European national road (E), what is the speed at which you are allowed to drive outside city limits?

options.text: 70 km/h
110 km/h
90 km/h.

questions.question: In a pedestrian area, marked as such, you are required to drive at a speed:

options.text: Of not more than 30 km/h
Of not more than 20 km/h
Of not more than 5 km/h.

questions.question: What are you obligations regarding traffic speed?

options.text: To comply with the statutory speed applicable to the road you travel
Adapt speed depending on road conditions so that you can perform any maneuver safely
No to exceed the speed limit in areas where radar equipment is installed.

questions.question: In which situation are you obliged to reduce speed?

options.text: At railway level crossings with barriers
At railway level crossing without barriers
At industrial railway level crossings.

questions.question: The driver of the vehicle in the image should drive at a maximum the speed of:

options.text: 80 km / h
90 km / h

questions.question: What is the maximum speed on highways?

options.text: 110 km / h
100 km / h

questions.question: What are your obligations, as a driver?

options.text: To drive at a speed, at least, equal to that prescribed by the indicator ‘Mandatory minimum speed’
Not to accelerate in intersections
To drive at a speed lesser than the indicated minimum speed.

questions.question: You are forced to drive at a speed not exceeding 30 km/h in towns, in the following situations:

options.text: In the action area of the warning indicator ‘Children between the hours 07.00-22.00’
In residential areas
When changing lanes.

questions.question: You are driving in a row of cars. How do you behave?

options.text: Overtake the row, if possible in a single movement
Maintain a proper distance from the car in front and watch out for other road users
Drive very close to the vehicle in front, not to be left behind.

questions.question: In which situation is it not permitted to increase the speed of a vehicle?

options.text: When another vehicle is overtaking you vehicle
In the action area of the indicator ‘Recommended speed’
When you drive on the first lane and there are vehicles moving with higher speeds on next lane, near the road axis.

questions.question: Speed will be reduced to the legal limit in the following situations:

options.text: In crowded market areas
At meeting the indicator ‘Stop’
When the road is covered with frost, ice, snow, slime or wet cubic (cobble) stones.

questions.question: After a heavy rain, it is necessary to maintain a significantly larger distance from the vehicle circulating in front?

options.text: Yes, because the braking space increases
No, because this leads to congestion
Yes, because you do not see the traffic signs.

questions.question: Travel speed must be reduced:

options.text: At the indicator ‘Give Way’.
When travelling in the direction opposite to trams, trolleybuses and buses stopped in stations on roads with a single lane
At the indicator ‘Priority over opposite traffic’.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed at which vehicles in categories A and B can drive outside city limits?

options.text: 130 km/h on highways, 100 km/h on expressways or European national roads and 90 km/h on other types of roads
110 km/h on highways, 90 km/h on expressways or European national roads and 80 km/h on other types of roads
130 km/h on highways and 80 km/h on other types of roads.

questions.question: At what speed should you drive when the road is covered with frost, ice, snow, slime or wet cubic stones?

options.text: The speed should be reduced to half of the speed limit.
The speed should not exceed 30 km/h in towns and 50 km/h outside towns
The speed should be reduced depending on the atmospheric conditions.

questions.question: What is forbidden in this situation?

options.text: The indicator is addressed only to drivers of public transport vehicles
To drive at speeds slower than 60 km/h
To drive at speeds greater than 60 km/h.

questions.question: In which of the following situations it is forbidden to increase speed?

options.text: When you are overtaken
In the action area of radar speed detection
At night.

questions.question: You drive in a row and maintain the distance from the vehicle in front. What else should to do?

options.text: To switch on the rear fog lamp
To see the right edge of the roadway through the side window
To stay in your lane and ensure your field of visibility.

questions.question: In this situation you must:

options.text: Not to exceed the speed of 30 km/h between 7.00-22.00 am, being an area frequented by children
Grant priority to cyclists crossing
Bypass the children’s playgrounds.

questions.questionsNumber: 48 The maximum speed on European national roadways (E), for a driver with less than a year of driving experience is:
questions.question: The maximum speed on European national roadways (E), for a driver with less than a year of driving experience is:

options.text: 110 km/h
80 km/h
90 km/h.

questions.questionsNumber: 49 What is the maximum speed at which you can drive?
questions.question: What is the maximum speed at which you can drive?

options.text: 60 km/h
50 km/h
40 km/h.

questions.question: What is the speed on public roads that are wet or covered with slime or snow?

options.text: The speed specified by regulations for the category of car you drive
The speed that will surely give you the safety to stop and without losing control
In this case the speed should not exceed 20 km/h.

questions.question: The lowest speed limit that public road administrators can fix for certain sectors within localities cannot be lesser than:

options.text: 10 km/h for trams and 30 km/h for all vehicles
20 km/h for trams and 40 km/h for all vehicles
30 km/h for trams and 50 km/h for all vehicles.

questions.question: What is the lowest speed limit that can be set within localities?

options.text: Not lesser than 30 km/h
Not less than 40 km/h
There is no legal provision.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed for traffic in residential areas?

options.text: 5 km/h
10 km/h
20 km/h.

questions.question: What dangers may arise when not wearing a seatbelt?

options.text: A collision even at a speed of about 20 km/h increases the risk of injury
Dangers can occur at speeds above 60 km/h
There is no risk of injury.

questions.question: You are required to reduce speed to the legal limit at pedestrian crossings without lights, but indicated by signs and markings, if:

options.text: The road has only one lane for each direction and pedestrians engage to cross
The road has at least two lanes
The crossings are located next to tram stations.

questions.question: You are forced to drive at a speed not exceeding 50 km/h outside towns, in the following situations:

options.text: When animals move alongside traffic on the road
When driving through tunnels
In pedestrian areas, marked as such.

questions.question: The maximum speed limit for a public road, a road administrator can set on certain sectors within localities, for vehicles in categories A and B cannot be greater than:

options.text: 50 km / h
80 km / h

questions.question: At what speed can you travel in conditions of fog, heavy rain, heavy snow, if visibility is reduced below 100 m?

options.text: Up to 50 km/h in towns and 60 km/h outside towns
Reduce speed to a limit where danger can be avoided
Up to 30 km/h in towns and 50 km/h outside towns.

questions.question: What is the speed limit on roads outside towns, other than motorways, expressways and European national roads (E)?

options.text: 70 km / h
90 km / h

questions.question: Why is it necessary to increase the distance to the vehicle in front of you, when driving on wet roads?

options.text: Because the tyre grip decreases and the braking space increases
Because you cannot see the stop indicator lights of the vehicle in front of you in time, when it brakes
Because the wheels of the vehicle in front of you may spray gravel on your windshield

questions.question: It is compulsory to reduce speed:

options.text: On pedestrian crossings
At the signals of border policemen
At the indicator ‘Dive Way’.

questions.question: In a residential area, you must travel at:

options.text: A compulsory minimum speed of 20 km/h
A speed of 20 km/h
A speed of 30 km/h.

questions.question: The phenomenon of aquaplaning generates the following hazards:

options.text: Splashing of water on the windscreen
Splashing of water on buildings and pedestrians
Loss of steering control.
